resources.string: A material design status bar replacement. No root needed.
An item with this name already exists.
You are missing one or more required icons.
Battery optimizations are already ignored! You can proceed to the next step.
Please enable the switch next to \"Status Service\".
Turn on the switch next to \"Status\". You may need to scroll down… a lot.
Please turn on the service titled \"Status Service\". You may need to scroll down for it to become visible.
Please grant access to external storage in order to use this functionality.
\'Status Service\' needs to be enabled in order to detect window changes to update the status bar. On some phones you may need to scroll to the bottom of the screen before it becomes visible.
Status uses this accessibility service to detect screen updates and notifications on older devices.

Status allows users to customize their status bar for better readability, aesthetic, or functionality, allowing them easier and faster use of their devices. \n\nStatus requires this accessibility service to detect the current app that is displaying on the screen in order to adapt to its color scheme and layout. It also uses this service to listen for notifications on older devices that do not have the NotificationListenerService API.

On some versions of android the app cannot use the standard notification listener API to display the notification icons. I have found a way to detect them through the accessibility service, however it cannot detect when a notification has been dismissed. Thus, it removes all notifications whenever the notification panel is opened. If you do not like this, you can either check for a firmware update or disable the notifications in the settings menu. Please note: this setting will break the notification icons on some devices. It is recommended not to enable this feature on versions of android that are newer than Lollipop.
The app needs to read incoming notifications in order to display notification icons on the status bar.
This app needs a few additional permissions in order to access parts of the phone relevant to the status bar. An explanation of why these are needed is provided in the Status\'s Play Store page.
Battery Optimizations will cause Status to stop working as the system will occasionally close Status to save battery life. You may have to scroll quite a bit before you find Status in the list.
The app needs to be able to draw an overlay on top of the screen so that it can show the status bar.
The clock will show in a 24 hour time format if this is turned on.
Choose whether to show the AM/PM indicator in the clock.
Shows the date next to the time in the clock.
Notifications will \'peek\' from the top of the screen whenever an important notification is received.
Set the amount of time for the app to show a heads-up notification for.
Shows the battery percentage next to the icon in the status bar.
Picks the status bar color from the current application. This may cause a significant decrease in performance depending on the device.
Set the color for the status bar to use on a specific screen. This will override any other color options provided the \'automatic status bar coloring\' option is enabled.

This option sets the status bar\'s background as the current wallpaper when the home screen is displayed. This setting will not work correctly on live wallpapers or if your home screen\'s scrolling wallpaper option is enabled.
Adjusts the color of the icons to avoid invisible or hard to see icons on light backgrounds.
Changes the color of the icons instead of the status bar background, which will be set to the default color.
If your phone has more than one sim card, this option will show two signal indicators instead of one.
Shows whether the data connection is 2G, 3G, 4G, or unknown/none (doesn\'t show anything).
The app will show a notification as a shortcut to set the color for an app if the a color has not been found.
This option allows you to enable or disable animating of the status bar background color. This may impact performance on slower devices.
This option lets you toggle the icon animations, which can drastically affect performance on slower devices if there are a lot of icons displaying at once.
This option handles how the status bar responds to the volume popup. If it does not overlap the status bar, this does not need to be checked. This might not work on some devices.
Shows confusing debug info about window changes.
Useful to prevent icons being cut off at the sides of the screen on phones with rounded screen edges.

This keeps the Status service in the foreground and prevents it from being automatically shut down due to conserve memory or battery life. Disabling this setting could improve performance, but it could also cause various stability issues on some devices.
Allows you to backup or restore all the settings in Status as a text file.
Only enable this if you are sure that all permissions have been granted and you know what you are doing! This can cause significant problems if used incorrectly.
Prevents Status from causing a burn-in on some screens by moving the icons around every two seconds.

Prevents icon \"sections\" from overlapping each other when there are too many icons displaying at once. This setting will cause battery drain with too many updates (music player notifications can be particularly taxing, especially if they update once every second), so be careful with it.
This setting will change the height of the status bar, but not the content underneath it! Setting this to 0 will cause Status to use the default height defined by the system.
Creates a fake (and really ugly) \"camera bump\" around the center aligned items in the status bar. Please don\'t ever enable this option.

Makes the background of the status bar transparent at all times. Keep in mind that the original status bar will still be visible behind this one; the only times this option might be useful is if you disable all status bar icons using SystemUI tuner on Android Nougat or above.
Status couldn\'t find a color to use for this application, so it\'s reverted to the default color. You can specify a color to use by clicking this notification.
The switch at the top of the screen allows you to enable and disable the customized status bar. Turn it on to try it!
Find the exact setting you want to change by using Status\'s search bar.
The help section is always being updated and contains almost all the issues that have been encountered by other users using this app.
Can\'t get the right color? Try picking the color from an image instead!
Enable or disable an icon by clicking the check box next to its name.
Change the order of the icons by pressing the up and down buttons next to an icon\'s name.
Don\'t want to modify an entire app?
Change individual screens by clicking the \'expand\' button below an app.
Status is open source and free to use without any advertisements or paid features. In order to support Status and other apps like it, please consider making a donation.

It appears that some of the permissions required by Status have not been granted. Without these permissions, some functionality may work incorrectly or be disabled. If you have already granted all the permissions and think that there may be an error, you can disable permission checking in the \'other\' section of the settings menu.

It appears that there are too many icons in the status bar and it doesn\'t have room to display them all. To prevent them from being cut off, you could enable the \"Prevent Overlap\" option in the settings or increase available space by reducing padding and icon scale.

h - Hours
 HH - Hours (24h)
 kk - Hours (24h)
 mm - Minutes
 a - AM/PM
 Z - Time Zone
 
 dd - Day of Month
 EEE - Day of Week
 MM - Month (numeric)
 MMM - Month
 yyyy - Year
Are you sure you want to reset all the app-specific preferences? This cannot be undone.
Android developer and professional cabbage eater.
Better known as the Oreo lord, this guy can add more butter to buttery interfaces.
The great lord of Material Design, yeah he makes icons and stuff.
A graphic designer, web designer, and the owner of technologx.com.
Created the spanish translations for the app.
Android developer, translated the app into Korean :D
Created Chinese translations for this app.
Obviously, it would be hard to make over 100 icons used in this app by myself, so (as well as the ones by the people above) the app uses icons from a few different sources.
Accounting for most of the icons in the app, Google Design has a large database of icons to choose from.
Made by many various contributors, this collection of icons contains useful resources unavailable from Google\'s site.
57,700 free flat icons in any format, size and color in 20 seconds.

item.p: \nGlide is a fast and efficient open source media management and image loading framework for Android that wraps media decoding, memory and disk caching, and resource pooling into a simple and easy to use interface.
\nSteppers is a view library for Android based on Material Design guidelines.
\nA library designed to make the organized execution of async processes in Android easy.
\nGson is a Java library that can be used to convert Java Objects into their JSON representation.

item.b: Why can\'t the status bar be transparent?
item.p: \nThis app works by making an overlay on top of the existing status bar, similar to how chat bubbles or a screen dimming app would work. This means that if it is made transparent, the system icons would be visible underneath it.

\nLag can be prevented mostly by minimizing the amount of times the status bar has to update. This can be done by disabling animations, resourced-based colors, and removing any icons that aren\'t completely necessary for the status bar to function.

item.b: The status bar uses the wrong color for my app.
item.p: \nStatus cannot detect color changes that happen after a screen is opened, only preset colors. This can make the colors of some apps slightly inaccurate, so it is recommended to set a neutral color for screens that can have multiple primary colors. For developers: Status mainly uses the \'R.attr.colorPrimaryDark\' or \'R.color.colorPrimaryDark\' resources to get the colors.

item.b: The status bar isn\'t showing notification icons.
item.p: \nFirst, check that you have the \'show notifications\' option in the \'settings\' tab enabled. Then open the setup screen (three dots -> setup). If you are running android 4.3 or higher, click on \'compatibility mode\' and turn on the switch at the bottom. If compatibility mode is already enabled, turning it off sometimes fixes the issue as well. Another useful thing to note is that sometimes clearing the app data can help fix issues similar to this one.

item.b: The status bar doesn\'t remove notifications until the notification panel is opened.
item.p: \nIf you are running android 4.3 or higher, open the setup screen (three dots -> setup), click on \'compatibility mode\', and make sure it is not enabled. If you\'re below android 4.3, this issue is due to a limitation of android and this is (unfortunately) the best I can do to support your device at the moment.

item.b: Why isn\'t the top part of my wallpaper aligned on the home screen?
item.p: \nIf the \'transparency on home screen\' option is enabled, the app will get a static image of the wallpaper and set it as the status bar\'s background whenever you are on your home screen. This can create a few issues with scrolling wallpapers, as it isn\'t possible to detect the current page of the home screen. If you are using a custom launcher, it\'s usually pretty easy to prevent the wallpaper from scrolling in the launcher\'s settings menu, but otherwise the only option you really have is to disable the transparency setting. It can also be affected by shadows at the top and bottom of the screen and devices that don\'t natively support the ability to have a transparent status bar.

item.b: Why is the status bar showing the wrong wallpaper on my home screen?
item.p: \nThe \'transparency on home screen\' option does not currently have support for live wallpapers - it will simply get the most recent image wallpaper instead.

item.b: My phone is dual sim, but it doesn\'t show the second signal strength icon.
item.p: \nStatus does not currently support dual sim as it works differently on almost every device and is difficult to implement. This is being worked on, however, and the app will be updated as soon as it is stable.

item.b: Why isn\'t the status bar visible on the lockscreen?
item.p: \nOn some devices, it is not possible to show the status bar over the system lock screen because of a potential security issue. A possible solution could be downloading a third party lock screen from the play store or just disabling the system lock screen.

item.b: How do you change the time format?
item.p: \nThe clock format can be changed through the \'time format\' option for the clock icon. The clock will replace certain characters inputted into the dialog with the associated variables, for example to show the time in a 24 hour format you would input \"HH:MM\", or to show the AM/PM indicator \"h:mm a\".

item.b: Why isn\'t the notification panel themed?
item.p: \nThe notification panel would take a lot of time to complete, and I feel it would be a better use of time to improve the speed and stability of the status bar before adding any more significant features, but that\'s not to say that it won\'t be added in the future.

item.b: Status isn\'t affected by my screen dimming app.
item.p: \nIn order to be shown over the status bar, Status needs to be drawn \'on top of\' everything else as well. This includes system overlays from other apps, including screen dimmers or chat bubbles.
